text: [intro jingle]
Cinnamon! is delicious.
I mean, have you ever had a churro?
But as my brother John will tell you that if you take a tablespoon full of it
and put it in your mouth and try to swallow it?
It's kinda impossible to do.
But that didn't stop John,
or, like 50'000 other people out there from attempting this utterly impossible thing,
so why, WHY isn't it possible?
First: Your Mouth - it produces about a liter of saliva a day.
That's quite a lot of saliva - which is just mucus,
enzymes and some other stuff...
But as gross as this might seem to you, we're swallowing this saliva all the time,
so at any given time, so you have like less than a tablespoon of it in your mouth.
So here's a tablespoon of cinnamon -
and here's a tablespoon of water - just being generous.
And yummy! As you can see, cinnamon is practically waterproof.
Some of it's still completely dry, and the rest is just hanging around on top of the water.
That's because cinnamon, the delicious spice that turns butter and sugar and bread into MAGIC,
is actually the dessicated, powdered bark of cinnamon trees.
And a main component of tree bark is cellulose,
which is both water resistant and resistant to the enzymes produced by humans.
Which is why we can't make a living out of eating sticks.
So while you're eating cinnaman toast, the bread and the sugar there get broken down by the digestive enzymes in your mouth.
But not the cinnamon.
The other components to cinnamon are basically just volatile organic compounds,
which give it that cake-y flavour that we all love.
From a purely medical standpoint,
the cinnamon challenge is pretty dangerous actually -
once your nervous system gets the signal that your mouth is been basically made waterproof,
plus, there's suddenly a whole bunch of finely ground powder in there -
kinda goes into panic mode. 'Cause you gotta breathe, right?
So your central nervous system starts telling you to breathe in gasps,
like you would if you were drowning.
Only that directs all that dry powder-y cinnamon down your pharynx, your larynx,
down your trachea, and into your lungs. And your lungs -
are /sensitive/, you guys!
All that tissue is pink and squishy like a pile of newborn baby bunnies.
And if there's one thing your body hates, it's a bunch of exotic material spicing up your sensitive alveoli!
So then, your immune system kicks in, sending over a bunch of white blood cells,
and the result is inflammation, maybe even pneumonia, or scarring of the lung tissue.
Or, you know, you could just choke to death - that's always an option!
Not to mention that cinnamon contains a chemical compound called Coumarin,
and when ingested in large quantities, can actually cause liver damage
in susceptible individuals.
So yeah, it's kinda [a] silly internet thing, but in 2011,
the American Association of Poison Control Centers
recorded 51 calls regarding teens and cinnamon,
and that's already increased to a 139 calls for 2012.
So! Let science be your guide - and instead of doing this stupid thing yourself,
why not just watch videos of literally thousands of YouTubers failing at it?
That's what we SciShow people call the Smart Way.
Thank you for watching this SciShow dose and for suggesting this topic for us.
If you have ideas for a future episode, or comments, or questions,
leave them on Facebook or Twitter for us
or, of course, in the comments below.
And if you wanna keep getting smarter with us, go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.
